case_vignette:
An 8-year-old male presents with 1 week of itchy blisters on the ears. He just recently returned from spring break with his family. He denies using any particular products on the ears before the rash. He says that this has occurred yearly for the last several years, always around the same time. He denies proximal muscle weakness. He denies flaking in the scalp. He denies any other symptoms. His family history is negative for any similar conditions. His physical examination is notable for itchy blisters on the ears, which are tender to the touch. The blisters are not weeping or crusting. The patient is otherwise healthy and has a normal growth pattern. The patient's mother reports that the blisters are worse when the patient is in the sun.
The patient's symptoms are consistent with a diagnosis of solar keratosis, also known as sunburn blisters. This condition is caused by prolonged exposure to the sun, and the blisters are a result of the skin's attempt to protect itself from the sun's rays. The patient's family history is negative for any similar conditions, which suggests that this is not a genetic condition. The patient's symptoms are consistent with a diagnosis of solar keratosis, and the patient's mother reports that the blisters are worse when the sun is out, which further supports this diagnosis.

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have itchy blisters on my ears that are tender to the touch.
Have you noticed these blisters on any other parts of your body?
No, I have not noticed blisters on any other parts of my body.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I have been experiencing these symptoms for 1 week.
Do you have any known allergies or recent exposures to new substances or environments?
I haven't used any particular products on my ears before the rash and just returned from spring break with my family.
Were you exposed to any plants or outdoor activities during your spring break where you might have come into contact with irritants?
I deny any specific exposures; however, I notice that the blisters get worse when I am in the sun.
Do you have any previous history of skin conditions or similar issues?
No, my family history is negative for any similar conditions, but I have experienced this same issue yearly for the last several years, always around the same time.
Final Diagnosis: Polymorphic Light Eruption (PMLE)
